title: Learning to localise sounds with spiking neural networks

author: Dan F. Goodman, École Normale Supérieure (ENS)

segmentation: Hi everyone.
OK, so.
When we hear a sound coming from a particular direction, what we actually here are two years is too differently transformed versions of the sound.
The power filters that transform them depend only on the direction the sound is coming from, and we can estimate this direction by inferring what the filters were.
Two critical aspects of the filtering are the arrival time difference between the two years and we can detect differences as small as 20 microseconds and the level difference between the two is.
In fact, there's not a single time and level difference for the entire sound, but rather a pattern of differences, one for each frequency component in the signal.
OK, so we can use this to actually localize sounds.

The filters depend on the precise shape of our ears and our head, and we can't know this a priority.
It also changes during development, so we need a method for learning it.
The basic idea of our model is to apply a series of neural filters in parallel to the signals received by the two years.
Some of these neuro filters will compensate for the acoustic filters.

A detectable pattern of neural synchrony between the two years which can be used to infer what the acoustic filters were.
This only depends on the on the filters and not on the sound, which is an important property for sound localization.

The neural filters we use are only frequency specific gains and delays and this can be easily implemented with real neurons and we detect the synchrony using coincidence detector neurons which are well known to exist in the auditory system.
